The '''Indian anti-corruption movement''', commencing in 2011, was a series of demonstrations and protests across India intended to establish strong legislation and enforcement against perceived endemic [[political corruption]].<ref name="bloomberg.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-21/indians-divide-over-policing-a-watchdog-world-view.html|title=Indians Divide Over Policing a Watchdog: World View|publisher=bloomberg.com|date=22 June 2011|accessdate=25 August 2011|first=Chandrahas|last=Choudhury|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> The movement was named among the "Top 10 News Stories of 2011" by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine.<ref name="anna time">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2101344_2101368_2101650,00.html|title=The Top 10 Everything of 2011: Number 10 – Anna Hazare's Hunger Fasts Rock India|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]|date=7 December 2011|accessdate=9 December 2011|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
The movement gained momentum from 5 April 2011, when anti-corruption activist [[Anna Hazare]] began a [[hunger strike]] at the [[Jantar Mantar]] in [[New Delhi]]. The chief legislative aim of the movement was to alleviate corruption in the [[Indian government]] through introduction of the [[Jan Lokpal Bill]]. Another aim, spearheaded by [[Ramdev]], was the repatriation of [[Indian black money|black money]] from Swiss and other foreign banks.
Grievances of mass protesters focussed on legal and political issues, including political corruption, [[kleptocracy]], and other forms of corruption. The movement was primarily one of non-violent [[civil resistance]], featuring demonstrations, marches, acts of civil disobedience, hunger strikes, marches and rallies, as well as the use of [[social media]] to organise, communicate, and raise awareness. The protests were [[nonpartisan]] and most protesters were hostile to attempts made by political parties to use them to strengthen their own political agendas.
==Background== {{See also|Corruption in India|List of alleged scams in India|Indian political scandals}} Issues regarding corruption in India have become increasingly prominent in recent years. The country was subject to socialist-inspired economic policies dating from independence in 1947 until the 1980s. Over-regulation, protectionism, and government ownership of industry led to slow economic growth, high unemployment, and widespread poverty.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Tushar |last1=Poddar |first2=Eva |last2=Yi |year=2007 |title=Global Economics Paper No: 152 |journal=Goldman Sachs Economic Research |page=23 |publisher=[[Goldman Sachs]] |doi= |url=http://www.usindiafriendship.net/viewpoints1/Indias_Rising_Growth_Potential.pdf |accessdate=17 June 2011 |format=PDF | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110724120152/http://www.usindiafriendship.net/viewpoints1/Indias_Rising_Growth_Potential.pdf| archivedate= 24 July 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] |year=2007 |title=Economic Survey of India, 2007 |journal=Policy Brief |publisher=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]]|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/17/52/39452196.pdf |accessdate=17 June 2011 |format=PDF | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110606112149/http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/17/52/39452196.pdf| archivedate= 6 June 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref> This system of bureaucratic control by government is called the [[License Raj]] and lies at the core of endemic corruption.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.forbes.com/2007/08/15/wipro-tata-corruption-ent-law-cx_kw_0814whartonindia.html |title=Will Growth Slow Corruption in India? |author=[[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] |date=15 August 2007 |work=Knowledge@Wharton |publisher=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=17 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110604044924/http://www.forbes.com/2007/08/15/wipro-tata-corruption-ent-law-cx_kw_0814whartonindia.html| archivedate= 4 June 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The [[Vohra Report]] of 1993, submitted by the former Indian Union [[Ministry of Home Affairs (India)#Home Secretary and other senior officials|Home Secretary]] [[Narinder Nath Vohra]], studied the issue of the [[criminalisation of politics]]. The report contained several observations made by official agencies on the criminal network which was virtually running a parallel government. It also discussed criminal gangs who enjoyed the patronage of politicians and the protection of government functionaries. It revealed that political leaders had become leaders of street gangs and rogue elements in the military. Over the years, criminals had been elected to [[Panchayati Raj|local bodies]], [[Vidhan Sabha|State Assemblies]], and the [[Parliament of India|Parliament]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3527710.stm |title=India's love affair with 'tainted' politicians |author=Seema Chishti |date=2 August 2004 |work= |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=17 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110709044843/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3527710.stm| archivedate= 9 July 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="wtcorruption">{{cite news |title=With Indian Politics, the Bad Gets Worse |author=Emily Wax |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/23/AR2008072303390.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=24 July 2008 |accessdate=17 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Dionne Bunsha |date=4 December 2004 |title=Dons in a new role |work=Frontline |volume=21 |issue=25 |url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/fline/fl2125/stories/20041217001704400.htm |accessdate=17 June 2011 }}</ref>
The [[Right to Information Act]] (RTI) of 2005 helped civilians work effectively towards tackling corruption. It allows Indian citizens to request information, for a fixed fee of {{INR}}10 ([[US$]]0.22), from a "public authority" (a body of Government or "instrumentality of State"). In turn, this public authority is required to reply to the request within thirty days. Activists have used this to uncover corruption cases against various politicians and bureaucrats – one consequence being that some of those activists have been attacked and even killed.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dying for data: the Indian activist killed for asking too many questions |author=Jason Burke |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/dec/27/india-rti-activists-deaths |work=The Guardian |date=27 December 2010 |accessdate=17 June 2011 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110709001509/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/dec/27/india-rti-activists-deaths| archivedate= 9 July 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In the years immediately preceding the 2011 anti-corruption protests there were various notable examples of alleged corruption in the country. These included the [[Adarsh Housing Society Scam]],<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article863396.ece | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=Adarsh Society: Army setting up court of inquiry | date=1 November 2010}}</ref> the [[2010 housing loan scam in India|2010 housing loan scam]],<ref>{{cite news| PSU banks, financial institutions – Economic Times | date=24 November 2010}}</ref> the [[Radia tapes controversy]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/radia-agent-of-foreign-intelligence-agencies-says-govt-affidavit/1/122879.html |title=Radia agent of foreign intelligence |publisher=[[India Today]] |date=10 December 2010 |accessdate=22 December 2011}}</ref> and the [[2G spectrum scam]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12056911 | work=BBC News | title=Indian opposition holds mass protest rally | date=22 December 2010}}</ref> In February 2011, the Supreme Court of India ordered all trial courts in the country to expedite handling of corruption cases<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/supreme-court-fast-tracks-corruption-cases-84632 |title=Supreme Court fast-tracks corruption cases |work=NDTV |date=10 February 2011 |accessdate=22 December 2011}}</ref> and the [[President of India]], [[Pratibha Patil]], stated that measures to ratify the [[United Nations Convention Against Corruption]] and other legislative and administrative measures necessary to improve transparency would be taken.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jurist.org/paperchase/2011/02/india-president-government-to-address-corruption.php |title=Paper Chase: India president: government to address corruption |publisher=JURIST |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=22 December 2011}}</ref> A month later, Chief Vigilance Commissioner [[P. J. Thomas (Indian administrative officer)|P.J. Thomas]] was forced to resign on charges of corruption by the Supreme Court.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12631887 | work=BBC News | title=India anti-corruption chief PJ Thomas forced to resign | date=3 March 2011}}</ref>
A worldwide 50-city [[Salt Satyagraha#Dandi March II|Dandi March II]], organised by [[People for Lok Satta]], took place in March 2011<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/dandi-march-ii-in-us-against-corruption-in-india-94692|title=Dandi March II in US against corruption in India |author=[[Indo-Asian News Service]] |date=28 March 2011 |work=NDTV |accessdate=17 June 2011}}</ref> as did the "Drive around Delhi" protest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/drive-around-delhi-to-demand-strong-lokpal-bill-news-national-ldnuaeejieb.html |title=Drive around Delhi to demand strong Lokpal Bill |author=[[Indo-Asian News Service]] |date=13 March 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Sify]]|accessdate=17 June 2011}}</ref>
==April 2011 protests== Anna Hazare wanted a joint committee to be formed, comprising members of the government and of civil society, to draft tougher anti-corruption legislation. Manmohan Singh, then [[Prime Minister of India]], rejected Hazare's demand and so Hazare began a hunger strike on 5 April 2011 at Jantar Mantar in Delhi.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Anna-Hazare-to-start-fast-unto-death-for-strong-Lokpal-Bill/Article1-681415.aspx|title=Anna Hazare to start fast unto death for strong Lokpal Bill |work=Hindustan Times |date=5 April 2011 |accessdate=5 April 2011}}</ref> He said that the fast would continue until the legislation was enacted.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12994855 |title=India activist Anna Hazare anti-graft fast stokes anger |work=BBC News |date=7 April 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110408055959/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12994855|archivedate=8 April 2011}}</ref> His action attracted considerable support, including some people who joined him in fasting.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/anna-hazares-antigraft-campaign-gathers-steam/148396-3.html |title=Thousands join Anna Hazare's anti-graft fight |work=IBN Live |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=6 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110511101056/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/anna-hazares-antigraft-campaign-gathers-steam/148396-3.html| archivedate= 11 May 2011}}</ref> Prominent representatives of opposition political parties, including the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] and the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]], indicated their support for Hazare and demanded government action.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110407/jsp/nation/story_13821901.jsp |title=BJP & CPM on activist side – Left party pledges support but wary of company |work=The Telegraph |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |first=J. P. |last=Yadav |location=Kolkata}}</ref> Hazare would not allow politicians to sit with him and those who tried to join, such as [[Uma Bharti]] and [[Om Prakash Chautala]], were turned away.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/uma-bharti-chautala-heckled-at-hazare-protest-96854|title=Uma Bharti, Chautala heckled at Hazare protest|date=6 April 2011|work=NDTV|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref>
Protests in sympathy with Hazare spread to various Indian cities, including [[Bangalore]], [[Mumbai]], [[Chennai]], and [[Ahmedabad]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-04-09/guwahati/29400372_1_anna-hazare-lokpal-bill-corruption |title=Northeast support to Hazare's |date=9 April 2011 |work=The Times of India |accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> Prominent figures from [[Bollywood]], sports and business indicated their support<ref>{{cite news|title=Jan Lokpal Bill: People from all over the country rally in support of Anna Hazare|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-08-22/news/29915186_1_anna-hazare-lokpal-bill-swami-agnivesh|accessdate=28 December 2011|work=The Economic Times|date=22 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Corporate India comes out in support of Anna Hazare |agency=PTI |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Corporate-India-comes-out-in-support-of-Anna-Hazare/Article1-682839.aspx |work=Hindustan Times |location=New Delhi |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> and there were also gatherings outside India, including in the US, Britain, France and Germany.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/1578597/report-indian-americans-rally-in-anna-hazare-s-support| title=Indian Americans rally in Anna Hazare's support| work=DNA| agency=IANS| date=22 August 2011 |accessdate=15 May 2013 |last=Kumar |first=Arun}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/video/special/support-for-anna-message-from-germany-536/208996|title=Support for Anna: Message from Germany|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2384499.ece |title=Indian expatriates take out anti-corruption rallies in Europe |work=The Hindu |date=22 August 2011 |accessdate=15 May 2013 |last=Suroor |first=Hasan}}</ref>
The government squabbled with the activists, insisting that the drafting committee would be headed by a government-appointed minister and not a civil society member as the protesters had demanded to avoid allowing the government to make the bill less powerful.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiablooms.com/NewsDetailsPage/newsDetails080411g.php |title=Anna Hazare: PM apprises President |date=8 April 2011 |work=India Blooms |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref>
On 6 April, Agriculture Minister [[Sharad Pawar]] resigned from the group of ministers that had been charged with reviewing the draft bill. Hazare had accused him of being corrupt.<ref>{{cite news |work=The Times of India |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Sharad-Pawar-quits-corruption-panel-as-support-for-Anna-Hazare-grows/articleshow/7888120.cms |title=Sharad Pawar quits corruption panel as support for Anna Hazare grows |date=7 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref> On 9 April, the government agreed to establish a joint committee.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/anna-hazares-fastuntodeath-to-continue/148700-3.html |title=Govt blinks on Lokpal bill, Anna to end fast |work=IBN Live |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011}}</ref> This came from a compromise that there would be a politician chairman, [[Pranab Mukherjee]], and an activist non-politician co-chairman, [[Shanti Bhushan]].<ref>{{cite news |title=People win anti-graft crusade, Hazare to end fast on Saturday |agency=PTI |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-04-08/india/29396095_1_anna-hazare-law-minister-home-minister|newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |location=New Delhi |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> Bhushan was one of the original drafters of the Lokpal Bill along with Hazare, Justice [[Nitte Santhosh Hegde|N. Santosh Hegde]], advocate Prashant Bhushan and RTI activist Arvind Kejriwal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Govt issues notification on committee to draft Lokpal Bill |agency=PTI |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article1637935.ece|work=The Hindu |location=New Delhi |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=20 June 2011}}</ref>
The first meeting of the Lokpal Bill drafting committee was held on 16 April. The government agreed to audio-record the committee's meetings and to hold public consultations before a final draft was prepared<ref name="NDTV2011-04-17">{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/kapil-sibal-first-meeting-of-lokpal-panel-fruitful-next-on-may%202-99224?trendingnow |title=New Lokpal Bill draft reduces differences |date=17 April 2011 |work=NDTV |accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref> but refused Hazare's demand that the proceedings be televised live.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anna Hazare seeks interpreter from next meeting |agency=PTI |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_anna-hazare-seeks-interpreter-from-next-meeting_1532843 |work=DNA |location=New Delhi |date=17 April 2011 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref>
==June protest== Ramdev had announced in April that he would launch a people's anti-corruption movement called [[Bharat Swabhiman Andolan]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/04/14/stories/2011041453631100.htm |title=Ramdev to launch people's movement to root out corruption |work=The Hindu |date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109235942/http://www.hindu.com/2011/04/14/stories/2011041453631100.htm |archivedate=9 November 2012 }}</ref> On 13 May it was announced that India had completed ratification of the UN Convention against Corruption, a process that had begun in 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-05-13/india/29539746_1_convention-fight-corruption-assets |title=India ratifies UN convention against corruption |work=The Times of India |date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |location=New Delhi}}</ref> Then, in the early days of June, four senior Union Ministers - [[Pranab Mukherjee]], [[Kapil Sibal]], [[Pawan Kumar Bansal]] and [[Subodh Kant Sahay]] - met Ramdev to discuss his concerns.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-05/india/29622561_1_ramdev-yoga-guru-hunger-strike |title=Ramdev fast: Chronology of events |work=The Times of India |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |agency=PTI}}</ref>
Ramdev supported Hazare's fast and subsequently led a second major protest at the [[Ramlila Maidan, New Delhi]] on 4 June 2011. He intended to highlight the need for legislation to repatriate black money deposited abroad. He demanded that such untaxed money should be declared to be the wealth of the nation and, further, that the act of caching money alleged to have been obtained illegally in foreign banks should be declared a crime against the state.<ref name="BBC20110602">{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13624741 |title=India yoga guru Baba Ramdev vows anti-graft fast |date=2 June 2011 |work=BBC News |accessdate=17 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110603021334/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13624741| archivedate=3 June 2011}}</ref>
The Ramlila Maidan was booked for 40 days to allow the protest to happen. Preparations included setting up toilet, drinking water and medical facilities, as well as a media centre.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/top-news/ramlila-ground-gets-ready-for-ramdev-s-fast_710292.html |title=Ramlila ground gets ready for Ramdev's fast |publisher=[[Zee News]] |date=2 June 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |agency=IANS| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024633/http://zeenews.india.com/news/top-news/ramlila-ground-gets-ready-for-ramdev-s-fast_710292.html| archivedate= 13 July 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref> Ramdev claimed that more than 100 million people were directly involved with the Bharat Swabhiman Andolan.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-05-19/nagpur/29559762_1_yoga-guru-baba-ramdev-bharat-swabhiman-yatra-patanjali-yog-samiti |work=The Times Of India |title=I aim to establish truth in corridors of power: Ramdev - The Times of India |date=19 May 2011}}</ref> Almost 3.2 million "[[netizens]]" joined the campaign.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/32-lakh-netizens-join-baba-ramdevs-campaign-against-corruption-108666 |title=32 lakh netizens join Baba Ramdev's campaign against corruption |work=NDTV |date=28 May 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 }}</ref>
On 5 June, police raided the Maidan, detaining Ramdev and removing his supporters after firing tear gas shells and [[lathicharge|lathicharging]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/midnight-police-swoop-baba-ramdev-detention-ends-protest-000000434.html |title=Midnight police swoop on Baba Ramdev, detention ends protest |publisher=Yahoo! News |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011 |agency=PTI |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110607054435/http://in.news.yahoo.com/midnight-police-swoop-baba-ramdev-detention-ends-protest-000000434.html| archivedate= 7 June 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref> 53 people, including 20 police officers, were treated for injuries.<ref>{{cite news |title=Indian police storm yoga guru's corruption protest |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/india/8558122/Indian-police-storm-yoga-gurus-corruption-protest.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=17 June 2011}}</ref> Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee called the police action "unfortunate" but added that the government had to do that as Ramdev had no permission to hold the protest.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/166660/pranab-mukherjee-justifies-crackdown.html |title=Pranab Mukherjee justifies crackdown |publisher=[[Deccan Herald]] |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |first=Anirban |last=Bhaumik}}</ref> Ministers said that permission had been granted for a yoga camp with 5,000 attendees but not for a political protest that had gathered 65,000 people.<ref name="NDTV2011-06-06">{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/ramdev-eviction-advani-and-co-pull-an-all-nighter-in-protest-at-rajghat-110379 |title=Ramdev eviction: Advani and co pull an all-nighter in protest at Rajghat |date=6 June 2011 |work=NDTV |accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref>
It was alleged that the action was not a spontaneous decision but had been planned for several days. The police said Ramdev had been informed shortly beforehand that permission to continue his agitation had been cancelled. By that time, over 5000 police officers had been prepared for action.<ref name="ET2011-06-06">{{cite news |title=Swoop not sudden, cops trailed Baba Ramdev for three days |first=Neeraj |last=Chauhan |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-06-06/news/29625873_1_baba-ramdev-yoga-camp-police-officers |work=The Economic Times |location=New Delhi |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref> There was an allegation that CCTV footage of the raid was missing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/police-stole-cctv-footages-of-ramlila-atrocities/20110606.htm |title='Police stole CCTV footages of Ramlila atrocities' India News |work=Rediff.com |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>
On 6 June, the [[National Human Rights Commission of India]] requested that reports of the events be provided within two weeks by the Union Home Secretary, Delhi Chief Secretary and the Delhi City Commissioner of Police.<ref name="NHRC issues notice to Centre, Delhi govt on Ramdev crackdown">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2081760.ece|title=NHRC issues notice to Centre, Delhi govt on Ramdev crackdown|date=7 June 2011|publisher=The Hindu|accessdate=6 June 2011|location=New Delhi}}</ref> Hazare responded to the events by holding a one-day hunger strike.<ref name=TOI2011-06-05>{{cite news |title=30 injured in police sweep at Ramlila Maidan |agency=Press Trust of India |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-05/india/29622682_1_lnjp-hospital-teargas-shells-lok-nayak-jai-prakash|newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |location=New Delhi |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=22 July 2011}}</ref> Protests were held in many parts of country, including the cities of Chennai, Bangalore, Mumbai, [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], [[Jammu]], and [[Lucknow]]. They also spread to [[Nepal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mangalorean.com/news.php?newstype=local&newsid=243096 |title=L'affaire Ramdev hits government hard, protests in Nepal |publisher=Mangalorean.com |date= |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/Nepal/Protests-in-Nepal-in-support-of-Ramdev/Article1-706463.aspx |title=Protests in Nepal in support of Ramdev |publisher=Hindustantimes.com |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-05/bangalore/29622803_1_baba-ramdev-anna-hazare-yoga-guru |title=City buzzes again, this time for Ramdev – Times of India |publisher=The Times of India |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Mumbai/Thousands-fast-in-Maharashtra-in-Ramdev-s-support/Article1-705711.aspx |title=Thousands fast in Maharashtra in Ramdev's support |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=4 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>
Ramdev said that a second phase of the Bharat Swabhiman Yatra would begin in October and would cover a distance of {{convert|100000|km}}.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-05-19/nagpur/29559762_1_yoga-guru-baba-ramdev-bharat-swabhiman-yatra-patanjali-yog-samiti |title=I aim to establish truth in corridors of power: Ramdev |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=19 May 2011 |agency=[[Times News Network]] |accessdate=15 August 2011 |location=[[Chandrapur]]/[[Yavatmal]]}}</ref>
===Aftermath===
====Civil society response==== Ramdev accused the government of not being serious about discussing issues of corruption and black money, alleging that government negotiator Kapil Sibal had cheated him through a "scheming and cunning" attitude. He alleged that there was a conspiracy to kill him and a "threat" was given to him during a meeting with senior ministers. He also claimed that the ruling government chairperson Sonia Gandhi and the [[United Progressive Alliance]] government will be responsible for any threat to his life and alleged that he was nearly strangled by the police.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/site/story/baba-ramdev-says-his-fast-will-continue/1/140452.html |title=Baba Ramdev targets Cong, Sonia; says agitation will continue |work=India Today |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> After being evicted from Delhi, Ramdev wanted to continue his fast from [[Noida]] but was denied permission to do so by the [[Uttar Pradesh]] government. He decided to continue his hunger strike and [[satyagraha]] from [[Haridwar]] only until 12 June 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/enraged-ramdev-continues-fast-in-haridwar/156952-3.html |title=Enraged Ramdev continues fast in Haridwar |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/site/story/baba-ramdev-continues-fast-in-hardiwar/1/140512.html |title=Baba Ramdev resumes fast in Haridwar, calls PM Sonia Gandhi's puppet |publisher=Indiatoday.intoday.in |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110713110136/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/site/story/baba-ramdev-continues-fast-in-hardiwar/1/140512.html| archivedate= 13 July 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/UP-says-no-entry--shaken-Ramdev-fasts-in-Haridwar/799877/ |title=UP says no entry, shaken Ramdev fasts in Haridwar |publisher=Indianexpress.com |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>
Hazare said there might have been some faults with Ramdev's agitation but that the beating up of people at night rather than in the day-time was a "blot on democracy" and that "there was no firing otherwise the eviction was similar to Jallianwala Bagh incident." He said that the "strangulation of democracy" would cause civil society to launch protests throughout the country to "teach government a lesson".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/anna-to-fast-in-support-of-baba-ramdev/Article1-706052.aspx |title=Anna to fast in support of Baba Ramdev |date=5 June 2011 |publisher=The Hindustan Times |accessdate=6 June 2011 |location=New Delhi |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610190548/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Anna-to-fast-in-support-of-Baba-Ramdev/Article1-706052.aspx |archivedate=10 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="Action against Ramdev blot on democracy: Anna Hazare">{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_action-against-ramdev-blot-on-democracy-anna-hazare_1551377|title=Action against Ramdev blot on democracy: Anna Hazare|date=5 June 2011|work=DNA |accessdate=5 June 2011|location=New Delhi}}</ref> Civil society leaders, such as [[Arvind Kejriwal]], said that the use of police force on non-violent sleeping protesters was undemocratic.<ref>{{cite news|agency=PTI |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2078919.ece |title=News / National: Civil society activists criticise police action at Ramlila Grounds |publisher=The Hindu |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.samaylive.com/nation-news/676488104/civil-society-political-parties-condemn-police-action-against-baba-ramdev.html |title=Civil society, political parties condemn police action against Baba Ramdev |publisher=English.samaylive.com |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>
====Government response==== Congress General Secretary [[Digvijay Singh (politician)|Digvijay Singh]] said that the government had reached an agreement before the protests were held.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Chunk-HT-UI-IndiaSectionPage-TopStories/Ramdev-is-a-cheat-Digvijaya-Singh/Article1-705903.aspx |title=Ramdev is a cheat: Digvijaya Singh |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110606111822/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Ramdev-is-a-cheat-Digvijaya-Singh/Article1-705903.aspx| archivedate= 6 June 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref> Prime Minister Manmohan Singh wrote to Ramdev, asking to cease-and-desist from holding the protests.<ref>{{cite news|last=Garia |first=Nikita |url=http://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2011/06/01/the-rise-of-baba-ramdev/ |title=Who Is Baba Ramdev? – India Real Time – WSJ |publisher=Blogs.wsj.com |date=1 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> [[Nationalist Congress Party]] General Secretary [[Tariq Anwar (politician)|Tariq Anwar]] said that "Both Hazare and Ramdev are blackmailing the government and they should first peep into their own hearts."<ref name="Ramdev 'blackmailing' government on graft issue: NCP">{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/ramdev-blackmailing-government-on-graft-issue-ncp/articleshow/8713363.cms|title=Ramdev 'blackmailing' government on graft issue: NCP|date=3 June 2011|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=3 June 2011|location=Meerut}}</ref> [[Pawan Kumar Bansal|Pawan Bansal]] commented on the midnight police action and said that "It was not a crackdown, we [the government] had to do it to maintain law and order".<ref>{{cite news |title= Govt had to act as Ramdev didn't see reason: Pawan Bansal |agency=PTI |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-05/india/29622824_1_baba-ramdev-yoga-guru-kapil-sibal |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |date=5 June 2011 |location=[[Chandigarh]] |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref>
[[All India Congress Committee]] secretary [[Janardan Dwivedi]] described Ramdev's protest as a "political game" by the Bharatiya Janata Party, pointing out that despite being treated in the same hospital as [[Nigamananda]], a protestor who had fasted for over two months regarding a different matter, Ramdev got more attention.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-ramdev-treated-nigamananda-left-to-die/20110614.htm |title=Ramdev treated, Nigamananda left to die? |work=Rediff |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=2015-09-03}}</ref>
====Political party response==== * The Bharatiya Janata Party called the police action to break up the hunger strike "undemocratic".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/it-is-an-attack-on-democracy-bjp/articleshow/8732357.cms |title=It is an attack on democracy: BJP |work=The Economic Times |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120124011307/http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/it-is-an-attack-on-democracy-bjp/articleshow/8732357.cms |archivedate=24 January 2012 }}</ref> [[Gujarat]] [[Chief Minister]] Narendra Modi strongly condemned the incident comparing atrocities on Ramlila ground with [[Ravana]]-[[Lila (Hinduism)|Lila]], adding that “It is one of the worst days of Indian history. The Prime Minister had said during the elections that he would bring back black money stashed in Swiss banks within 100 days of coming into power. But today, it is two years and nothing has happened.”<ref name=ib>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiablooms.com/NewsDetailsPage/newsDetails050611h.php |title=Oppn, Hazare slam govt on Ramdev |publisher=Indiablooms.com |date= |accessdate=16 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110713025220/http://www.indiablooms.com/NewsDetailsPage/newsDetails050611h.php| archivedate= 13 July 2011}}</ref> L. K. Advani said that the police action reminded him of the [[Jallianwala Bagh massacre]] and added that the police crackdown on Ramdev is a "naked fascism".<ref name=ib/> Leader of the Opposition in the Lok Sabha [[Sushma Swaraj]] said: "This is not democracy. .. the police cannot alone have taken such a step. It had the approval of the Prime Minister and full approval of the Congress President.<ref name=ib/> * [[Bahujan Samaj Party]] leader and [[Uttar Pradesh]] Chief Minister, [[Mayawati]], condemned the government's midnight crackdown on Ramdev and demanded that Supreme Court of India order an investigation into the incident stating that justice cannot be expected from the Central Government.<ref name=bsp>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyindia.com/show/443623.php |title=Mayawati, Mulayam pull up Centre over police action on Ramdev |publisher=Dailyindia.com |date= |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=k/> * The [[Samajwadi Party]] chief [[Mulayam Singh Yadav]] condemned the incident saying that the action shows Centre has lost its mental balance. Charging the ruling [[Indian National Congress]] party, Yadav further said: "A Congress leader said that Baba is a thug. I want to say that Congress is the biggest thug and it should introspect its deeds.<ref name=bsp/> "The government swooped down on Ramdev and his supporters as if it were carrying an attack on a foreign enemy," Yadav told reporters at a press conference.<ref name=k/> * [[Rashtriya Janata Dal]] leader [[Lalu Prasad Yadav]] accused Ramdev of being a front for the [[Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-05/india/29622693_1_baba-ramdev-yoga-guru-rss |title=Ramdev is a front for RSS' activities: Lalu |publisher=The Times of India |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> * The [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] termed the police action at the protest site of Ramdev as "deplorable and shortsighted". However, they found fault with the yoga guru for making the issue of black money "farcical" by entering into a secret agreement with government.<ref>{{cite news|agency=PTI |url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/cpi-m-deplores-police-action-against-ramdev-092500684.html |title=CPI-M deplores police action against Ramdev |publisher=In.news.yahoo.com |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717083939/http://in.news.yahoo.com/cpi-m-deplores-police-action-against-ramdev-092500684.html |archivedate=17 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> "The manner in which Ramdev's demands were drafted and the way in which he has conducted his interactions with the government, coming to a secret agreement to withdraw the hunger strike on the basis of assurances, then reneging and announcing its extension trivialised the seriousness of the issue of black money and made it farcical," the party said.<ref name=k/> * The [[Shiv Sena]] strongly condemned the police action against Ramdev.<ref name=k>{{cite news|url=http://expressbuzz.com/nation/political-parties-condemn-midnight-drama/281385.html |title=Political parties condemn midnight drama |publisher=Expressbuzz.com |date=5 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> * [[Nitish Kumar]], leader of [[Janata Dal (United)]], and the Chief Minister of [[Bihar]], condemned the attack saying "It is a major blow to democracy and an attack on the democratic rights of the people ... It is also an attack on the fundamental rights of the citizens.”<ref name=ib/>
====''Suo Moto'' cognizance by the Supreme Court==== The Supreme Court of India issued notices to the Union Home Secretary, Chief Secretary of Delhi, Delhi administration, and Delhi Police Commissioner expressing its displeasure that the entire contents of the petition{{clarify|reason=what petition?|date=September 2015}} had been leaked to the media before the matter came up for hearing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/explain-drama-at-ramlila-maidan-sc-to-centre/20110606.htm |title=Explain drama at Ramlila maidan: SC to Centre – Rediff.com India News |work=Rediff.com |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> On 29 August 2011, the Court blamed the Delhi Police for the forcible eviction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.oneindia.in/2011/08/29/baba-ramdev-evicted-from-ramlila-sc-blamed-delhi-police.html |title=Delhi: Baba Ramdev smiling, police crying? SC slams cops |publisher=News.oneindia.in |date=29 August 2011 |accessdate=9 September 2011}}</ref>
==August protests== By mid-June, the Jan Lokpal drafting committee was in disagreement and government representatives said that if a consensus was not reached then two drafts would be sent to the Cabinet, being those of the government and of the civil society representatives. Hazare declared that if the government version of the bill was passed by parliament, he would start a hunger strike from 16 August 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-govt-agreed-to-only-15-of-the-71-points-of-lokpal-bill/20110616.htm |title='Let them put us in Tihar' |work=Rediff.com |date=16 June 2011 |accessdate=15 August 2011 |first=Sahim |last=Salim}}</ref> On 15 August, he announced that the fast would begin on the following day.<ref name="Section 144 imposed as Team Anna, govt headed for showdown">{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/India-against-corruption-Ban-orders-imposed-at-Hazare-protest-venue/articleshow/9614650.cms|title=Section 144 imposed as Team Anna, govt headed for showdown |work=The Times of India |date=15 August 2011| accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref>
[[File:IAC-Protesters-in-Pune.jpg|thumb|India Against Corruption protesters in [[Pune]], April 2011]]
The government imposed [[Unlawful assembly#Section 144|Section 144]] at Jayaprakash Narayan Park, Rajghat and [[Delhi Gate (Delhi)|Delhi Gate]], prohibiting assembly of five or more people.<ref name="Section 144 imposed as Team Anna, govt headed for showdown"/> Hazare was detained by Delhi Police in the early morning of 16 August before he could start his hunger strike. More than 1200 supporters, including members of Team Anna, were also taken into preventative custody. Most of the supporters, including Kiran Bedi and Shanti Bushan, were released by early evening.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/17/world/asia/17india.html?_r=1&ref=world| title=New Delhi Police Arrest Leader of Anti-Corruption Protest and Hundreds of Others| publisher=The New York Times |date=16 August 2011| accessdate=16 August 2011| first=Jim| last=Yardley}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/team-anna-detained-for-defying-orders-govt/175962-3.html| title=Team Anna detained for defying orders: Govt |work=IBN Live |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Kiran Bedi, Shanti Bhushan released|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Kiran-Bedi-Shanti-Bhushan-released/Article1-733955.aspx|accessdate=17 August 2011 |work=Hindustan Times |date=16 August 2011}}</ref> Hazare was remanded to [[Tihar Jail]] after he refused to sign a personal bail bond. Within hours, a [[Team Anna]] spokesperson said that he had begun a hunger protest in custody and was not accepting even water to drink. The arrests set off a groundswell of protests across the country and were condemned by opposition political parties and some non-government organisations. Parliament was unable to conduct business after an uproar on the issue forced an adjournment for the day.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2362611.ece |title=Anna arrest echoes in Parliament, both Houses adjourned |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2011 |first=Aarti |last=Dhar |location=New Delhi}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=The Hindu |agency=PTI |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/nationwide-protests-against-annas-detention/article2362286.ece?ref=relatedNews |title=Nation-wide protests against Anna’s detention |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref> In Chennai, Mahatma Gandhi's secretary, V. Kalyanam, led the protesters. He said {{quote|India will get a sure gold medal if corruption is entered as an item in the Olympic Games. We may not be a force in football or athletics or hockey. But India is the undisputed global leader in corruption.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_exclusive-in-chennai-gandhis-secretary-leads-pro-anna-hazare-protests_1576604| title=In Chennai, Gandhi's secretary leads pro-Anna Hazare protests |work=DNA |date=16 August 2011| accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref>}}
Delhi police commissioner B. K. Gupta said that the police were not keen for Hazare be sent to judicial custody and had been prepared to release him if he had given an undertaking not to break Section 144 and ask his supporters also not to do so. In a message released after his detention, Hazare said this was the beginning of the "second freedom struggle" and he called on people to participate in a "[[Jail Bharo Andolan|jail bharo]]" agitation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/anna-in-tihar-jail-govt-faces-opposition-public-anger-updated-126946 |title=Anna in Tihar jail: Govt faces opposition, public anger |work=NDTV |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref>
Hazare on 16 August asked government employees across the country to go on mass leave to show solidarity with the movement. Union Home minister [[P. Chidambaram]] hoped they would not respond, describing the call as "completely wrong." Hazare's close associate and lawyer [[Prashant Bhushan]] urged government servants to join their cause and take a mass leave for a day and join the protests in their city.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/PC-hopes-govt-employees-reject-mass-leave-call/Article1-733993.aspx |title=PC hopes govt employees reject mass leave call |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2011 |agency=PTI |location=New Delhi}}</ref>
===Hazare's release=== It was decided to release Hazare after Prime Minister Manmohan Singh met party General Secretary Rahul Gandhi, who disapproved of the arrest, on the evening of 16 August.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/govt-blinks-likely-to-release-anna-sources/176167-3.html |title=Govt blinks, to release Anna Hazare: sources |work=IBN Live |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref> Congress sources said that the Government decided to release him and his supporters after coming to the conclusion that keeping him in jail would disrupt law and order unnecessarily. Over 1,500 people who had been detained for taking part in protests demanding Hazare's release were also freed. However, Hazare then refused to leave the jail until the government agreed to give unconditional permission to hold protests at [[Jai Prakash Narayan National Park]].<ref name="ndtv">{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/anna-hazare-to-be-released-from-tihar-jail-tonight-say-sources-126962| title=Anna Hazare refuses to come out of Tihar Jail| work=NDTV |date=16 August 2011| accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref>
Hazare agreed to leave after Delhi Police granted him permission to fast for 15 days at Ramlila Maidan, a larger venue than Jai Prakash Narayan National Park. However, he had to spend another night in jail because the venue was not ready.<ref name="Anna Hazare accepts Delhi Police offer, to fast for 14 days">{{cite news|title=Anna Hazare accepts Delhi Police offer, to fast for 14 days|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-18/india/29900380_1_anna-hazare-tihar-jail-manish-sisodia|accessdate=18 August 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=18 August 2011}}</ref> Greeted by crowds, he left jail on 19 August for the 25,000-capacity Ramlila Maidan, where he said that he would not leave until the bill was passed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Will not leave Ramlila Ground till Jan Lokpal Bill is passed: Anna Hazare|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-19/india/29904776_1_second-freedom-struggle-anna-hazare-ramlila-maidan|accessdate=19 August 2011|work=The Times of India|date=19 August 2011}}</ref>

==Parliamentary debate== {{main|2011 parliamentary debate on anti-corruption legislation}} A debate on the Jan Lokpal bill was held in Parliament on 27 August 2011. With Hazare demanding three principles, (i) citizen charter, (ii) lower bureaucracy to be under Lokpal through an appropriate mechanism and (iii) establishment of [[Lok Ayukta]]s in the states, both houses of Parliament agreed to the principles.<ref>{{cite news|title=Victory for Anna, Parliament adopts 'sense of House' on Lokpal Bill|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-27/india/29935496_1_lokpal-bill-anna-hazare-pranab-mukherjee|accessdate=27 August 2011|work=The Times of India|date=27 August 2011}}</ref> Hazare announced that he would break his fast on 28 August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anna Hazare to end fast tomorrow|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-08-27/india/29935081_1_anna-hazare-bedi-tweeted-kiran-bedi|accessdate=27 August 2011|work=The Times of India|date=27 August 2011}}</ref>
==December protests== On 11 December, Hazare sat on a day-long fast at Jantar Mantar. This protest was against proposals of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on the anti-graft measure. It was the first at which politicians shared the stage with Hazare, with leaders of the BJP, Communist Party of India (Marxist), Communist Party of India, [[Janata Dal]], [[Akali Dal]], [[Telugu Desam Party]] and [[Biju Janata Dal]] participating in the public debate on the Lokpal bill.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anna Hazare on one-day fast for strong Lokpal Bill|url=http://truthdive.com/2011/12/11/anna-hazare-on-one-day-fast-for-strong-lokpal-bill.html|newspaper=truthdive.com|accessdate=13 December 2011|date=11 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=8 parties on Anna stage, Congress feels heat|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/8-parties-on-anna-stage-congress-feels-heat/886653/|accessdate=13 December 2011|newspaper=[[Indian Express]]|date=12 December 2011}}</ref>
The expected introduction of the Lokpal bill in the Lok Sabha did not occur. Instead, the Food Security Bill was first introduced and subsequently the process of the Lokpal Bill was hindered by procedural and party political issues.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lokpal to be introduced by Indian Government in Lok Sabha, Food Security Bill passed by the Lok Sabha|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/lokpal-bill-lok-sabha-parliament/1/165380.html|work=India Today |accessdate=22 December 2011 |date=22 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cabinet to include Muslim Minorities in the Lokpal Bill|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/lokpal-bill-lok-sabha-parliament/1/165380.html|newspaper=indiatoday.intoday.in |accessdate=22 December 2011 |date=22 December 2011}}</ref> The Lokpal Bill that had been proposed had been discarded by the government, who put forward a revised proposal, along with a constitutional bill, in an attempt to resolve the issues that were being raised during the session regarding [[Reservation in India|reservation]] for minorities and other under-represented groups.<ref>{{cite news|title=Indian Government Presented Lokpal Bill 9th Time in Indian Parliament|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/lalu-terms-lokpal-bill-as-anti-minority-lok-sabha-adjourned/articleshow/11204284.cms|newspaper=economictimes.indiatimes.com|accessdate=22 December 2011|date=22 December 2011}}</ref>
Hazare announced on 22 December that a hunger strike would take place between 27–29 December, with a Jail Bharo Andolan subsequently to pressurise the Government.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anna Hazare to start Hunger Strikes and Jail Bharo Andolan|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_new-lokpal-bill-introduced-in-lok-sabha_1628906|work=DNA|accessdate=22 December 2011|date=22 December 2011}}</ref> He began his fast on 27 December at the [[Bandra Kurla Complex]] in Mumbai rather than in Delhi because of the cold climate in the latter city.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anna begins fast in Mumbai as Lok Sabha debates Lokpal in Delhi|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-27/india/30561065_1_anna-supporters-juhu-beach-anna-hazare|accessdate=27 December 2011|work=The Times of India|date=27 December 2011}}</ref> Turn-out was well below expectations, which was perhaps in part because of the cold weather.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low turn out at Anna Hazare's fast in Mumbai on day 1 |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/gandhian-anna-greeted-by-asparse-gathering-in-mumbai/1/166128.html |accessdate=28 December 2011 |work=India Today |date=28 December 2011}}</ref> IAC members asked him to end this latest fast because of his poor health but he refused. Hazare had been suffering from cold and mild [[fever]] for few days previously.<ref>{{cite news|title=Team Anna appeals to Hazare to end fast|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-27/india/30561061_1_anna-hazare-suresh-pathare-kiran-bedi-today|accessdate=27 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=27 December 2011}}</ref>
On the second day of the fast, a day ahead of schedule, Hazare repeated his threat to campaign against Congress in the five poll-bound states for not bringing a strong Lokpal. His deteriorating health and the low turn-out across the country were among the reasons for then ending the fast. He said that the movement was not stopped, merely postponed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anna Hazare calls off fast, cancels jail bharo campaign|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-28/india/30564941_1_jail-bharo-anna-hazare-general-elections|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=28 December 2011}}</ref> He also announced the cancellation of the "Jail Bharo" movement due to his bad health.
===Parliament debate=== The Lok Sabha debated the Lokpal Bill on 27 December 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sushma Swaraj punches holes in government's Lokpal bill|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Sushma-Swaraj-punches-holes-in-governments-Lokpal-bill/articleshow/11265687.cms|accessdate=27 December 2011|work=The Times of India|date=27 December 2011}}</ref> The debate resulted in the bill being passed to the Rajya Sabha but the new nine-man Lokpal panel was not given constitutional status because the government failed to get the necessary two-thirds majority of MPs present.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lokpal Bill in Rajya Sabha: Govt hunts for numbers with eye on Mamata|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/lokpal-bill-in-rajya-sabha-govt-hunts-for-numbers-with-eye-on-mamata-161368|accessdate=28 December 2011|work=NDTV|date=28 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Lokpal Bill passed in Lok Sabha, but no constitutional status|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/lokpal-bill-passed-in-lok-sabha-but-no-constitutional-status-161294|accessdate=28 December 2011|work=NDTV|date=28 December 2011}}</ref>
The Lokpal Bill was sent for review to the Indian President, Pratibha Patil, on 28 December 2011. This is standard operating procedure for any legislation that will have financial implications. She later gave her assent for the Bill to be tabled in the Rajya Sabha.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lokpal Bill in Rajya Sabha: Govt hunts for numbers with eye on Mamata|work=NDTV|accessdate=28 December 2011|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/lokpal-bill-in-rajya-sabha-govt-hunts-for-numbers-with-eye-on-mamata-161368|date=28 December 2011}}</ref>

===Protests=== Hazare declared that the protest movement would recommence and a mark of protest he sat on hunger strike on 25 March 2012 for one day.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.oneindia.com/2008/05/15/videos-china-quake-death-toll-rises-to-15-000.html|title=China quake: Death toll rises to 15,000|date=15 May 2008|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> A month later, Hazare sat a token one-day fast focussed on remembrance of whistle-blowers such as [[Narendra Kumar]] and [[Satyendra Dubey]] who had died as a result of their support for the anti-corruption cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/anna-to-protest-at-jantar-mantar-on-march-25/242015-37.html|title=Anna to protest at Jantar Mantar on March 25|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> On 3 June, Hazare undertook another one-day fast at [[Jantar Mantar]], where he was joined by [[Ramdev]], a [[yoga]] [[guru]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/anna-hazare-baba-ramdev-to-fast-on-june-3-200055?pfrom=home-otherstories|title=Anna Hazare, Baba Ramdev to fast on June 3|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
Hazare and Bedi reformed Team Anna, while Kejriwal and some others split from the erstwhile apolitical movement with the intention of forming what was to become the [[Aam Aadmi Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/what-is-the-aam-aadmi-party-all-about/1/234564.html|title=So what is the Aam Aadmi Party all about|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
Jantar Mantar was the scene of an "indefinite" fast that began on 25 July and involved various members of Team Anna,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/team-anna-to-launch-indefinite-hunger-strike-today-for-lokpal-bill-anna-will-join-fast-from-july-29-247251?pfrom=home-lateststories|title=Team Anna launches indefinite hunger strike today for Lokpal Bill; Anna will join fast from July 29|publisher=|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> although Hazare was not involved until four days later. The focus on this occasion was a protest against the government's refusal of an inquiry against the prime minister and 14 cabinet ministers, whom they had accused of corruption.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} The fast ended on 3 August.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/india-against-corruption-team-anna-breaks-fast-to-form-party-for-cleaning-system/articleshow/15340341.cms |publisher=The Times Of India | title=India Against Corruption: Team Anna breaks fast, to form party for 'cleaning system' | date=3 August 2012}}</ref> Three days later, Hazare announced that since the government seemed to be unready to enact the Jan Lokpal Bill, he and his fellow activists had decided to end their fast, to discontinue talks with the government and to cease any protests under the Team Anna name.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/anna-hazare-disbands-team-anna_792022.html|title= Anna Hazare disbands ‘Team Anna’ | date= 6 August 2012}}</ref>
